DOC.HEAD: Jacksonville NAACP Says Work Will Continue Despite Bomb Scare
Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 11th, ``We've come ..., to UPDATE with comment from white Council member. Willye in 9th graf is correct
LaserPhoto JV1
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights leaders said Wednesday they've made progress in this northeast Florida city, but the mailing of a bomb to NAACP headquarters recalls recent racial tensions that had begun to fade. The bomb disarmed here Tuesday was similar to devices which killed a federal appeals court judge and a Savannah, Ga., civil rights leader. Bombs mailed to the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta and to the Jacksonville office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were disarmed without causing any damage or injuries. Possible links to NAACP school desegregation efforts have been identified in all four cases, leading to theories that a racist group may be responsible. Racial tensions were heightened here in September when three black City Council members were ordered arrested after they walked out of a meeting to protest lack of funding for predominantly black areas in the city budget. One of them, attorney Deitra Micks, was arrested in a City Hall women's room and hauled back to the council meeting in handcuffs. The arrests were ordered by City Council President Tillie Fowler, who is white, so the council would have a quorum. ``And all of a sudden this happened, so it just brings up this whole issue of race again,'' the Rev. John Newman, a black minister, said Wednesday. ``Jacksonville is sitting on a racial powder keg, I'm sorry to report.'' Black leaders said they were angry about Tuesday's discovery of the bomb, but it will not deter them from their work. ``We will go on with our business as usual. We will not let this incident stop us from doing the job we have set out to do,'' said Willye Dennis, the local president of the NAACP. She received the explosive package Monday, but didn't have time to open it then. She had a more optimistic view of racial tension in the city. ``We've come a long way in Jacksonville, but we have a long way to go,'' she said. City Council member Terry Wood, who is white, said he believes tensions have eased since the walkout. ``But there are elements on both sides who can point to certain events and say improvements are superficial,'' said Wood. Newman, pastor of the Mount Calvary Baptist Church, said the organization has received criticism from both whites and blacks for its positions. ``On one hand we have threats from whites, perhaps racists, who want to destroy us because of positions of ideology ... and on the other hand, to try to stop drugs we have threats from blacks who happened to be drug dealers who want to blow us away,'' Newman said. The FBI said Wednesday that all four bombs had Georgia postmarks or return addresses. FBI agent William Hinshaw, in charge of the Atlanta office, said the first parcel bomb, addressed to federal Judge Robert S. Vance, was mailed last Thursday from Newnan, Ga., to Vance's home in Mountain Brook, Ala., a suburb of Birmingham. Vance was killed and his wife was seriously injured. The bomb that killed Savannah, Ga., alderman and attorney Robert E. Robinson on Monday is believed to have been mailed Friday from Macon, Hinshaw said. The bomb found in Jacksonville also was mailed Friday from Macon, he said. Another bomb was mailed Saturday from the Atlanta area to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals clerk's office in Atlanta, Hinshaw said. The investigation is concentrating in part on possible links to NAACP school desegregation efforts: _ The 11th Circuit hears federal appeals from Georgia, Florida and Alabama, including desegregation cases. _ Vance, an 11th Circuit judge, wrote the court's September ruling in favor of the Jacksonville NAACP in its desegregation suit against Jacksonville schools. _ Robinson was the Savannah NAACP's local counsel and helped with an NAACP suit against the Savannah schools. The NAACP lost that case at the 11th Circuit, and the three-judge panel did not include Vance. _ Robinson also had advised the Jacksonville NAACP chapter in its desegregation case, according to a Jacksonville activist, the Rev. Fred Newbill.
